He had been with Mr Rush, and renewed his application for an office; but without saying what office— Johnson Hellen came in from Rockville, to spend Christmas Holidays with us. My Sons John and Charles dined with a large party at Baron Tuyll the Russian Minister’s the annual banquet on the Emperor Alexander’s birth day— Between nine and ten in the Evening, Mr J. W. Taylor who had also dined there called on me and spoke again in behalf of General Brown, concerning the appointment of Coll. Croghan as Inspector General of the Army. Taylor said Brown had been with him again; exceedingly dissatisfied at this nomination, and urgent even to tears, intreating that I would make the nomination from the line of the army— Insisting that in all services that Officer is always and peculiarly designated by the commanding General— That all the Officers of the army will consider it as a slight upon the army itself, and the result of unkind feelings towards them— I desired Taylor to say to General Brown that these impressions were entirely erroneous— That my feelings towards him and the army were altogether friendly. That I hoped to have in the course of the Administration some opportunity to give him an unequivocal proof of it— That the nomination first intended to have been made was forborne out of deference to his wishes; that if I had known that he took the matter so deeply to heart I would have asked the Secretary at War to reconsider his recommendation of Croghan. But it was now too late. He had made the recommendation in writing; it was on record at the War Department— I had promised and prepared to send it in— I could not change it now without justly incurring the imputation of wavering and indecision—taking the bias of the last person who may have access to me; and to be relied upon for anything— Taylor said he entirely agreed with me in this opinion, and would immediately report to the General my determination and the reasons upon which it is founded—
25. VI. Christmas day— Walk round Tyber Square 40 minutes— Fog— Rain

Rode to the Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick’s, and heard the Mass performed. Also a Discourse upon the day, delivered by the Bishop of Charleston, John England.
He spoke from the platform in front of the altar; without pulpit, and without taking a text— With allusion to the festival of the day he considered the influence of Christianity upon the fortunes and happiness of mankind, by describing the condition of human Society before that time, and by comparing it with that of the ages subsequent to the birth of Christ, to the present time. This review opened a very wide field, upon which he largely descanted. He was at least an hour and a half speaking—without notes, and apparently without preparation, at least as to the language— He defended the Church of Rome against the charge of opposing the progress of physical Science, and particularly with regard to Copernicus and Galileo— He expressed very liberal principles of religious toleration, and besought charitable contributions for the Establishment of a Catholic theological seminary at Charleston—for which a Collection was taken up. A long Mass, followed after the Bishop’s discourse, and notice was given that he would preach again at four O’Clock on the same subject— It was half past two before I got home, and the weather was so bad that I did not again go out this day.
26 VI:15. Last Solstitial day. Sun rose 7:23. Clear. Job. 1.2.3.

Coll. R. M. Johnson came to introduce Mr Mosely a Citizen of Kentucky. T. P. Moore is one of the Representatives from Kentucky and came also for a morning visit— Mr Rush called on the subject of the strange transactions in the Custom House at Philadelphia— I suggested to him the impression of a necessity to remove the Collector of the Port, in which both he and Governor Barbour who came in while we were conversing on the subject fully concurred— Barbour indeed was of opinion that all the Officers of the Customs at Philadelphia, ought to be displaced, and an entire new set appointed in their places— Rush had received several Letters warmly recommending General Cadwalader for Collector— I told him that if Cadwaladars Politics were to form no objection, I thought Hopkinson much better qualified; and with higher pretensions, in every respect, to which he fully assented. Barbour thought Hopkinson’s politics an insuperable objection— Mr Rush is to consult with Mr Clay and Mr Southard on the subject— Barbour brought me a Talk from the Mackintosh deputation of Creek Indians— Messrs.Wurtz, Hemphill and Miller, are Representatives from the City and County of Philadelphia, and came to me to urge the claim of the Lippincott’s to have delivered up to them the Teas in the Custom House, upon their payment of the duties on the same teas, the property of which had been assigned by Edward Thomson to them. Mr Wurtz principally pressed the claim of the Lippincott’s I asked him in candour to say whether he spoke altogether as a public man, or as a friend or agent of the Lippincott’s— Mr Rush had understood the latter; but Wurtz assured me that he acted solely as a public man, in behalf of some of his Constituents— I told him the property could not at present be given up to the Lippincott’s as from the Reports of the Collector, the Lippincott’s themselves were implicated in some degree of suspicion— Wurtz was a little discomposed at the question whether he had any particular interest concerned in this Affair— General Brown came to introduce Mr Anderson of N York, and Major Worth, the second in command, at West-Point, who signified to me the wish to be appointed Inspector General of the army— I observed it was too late, for a nomination of
another person had already been sent into the Senate— He then mentioned to me his desire to obtain a brevet rank for ten years service with a brevet rank obtained during the late War, for distinguished merit in the field— General Gaines who has just returned from the North, paid a morning visit— I dined with all the family at Mr Frye’s— It was a Christmas dinner— Walked there with my two Sons, and late in the Evening home. Chess after dinner with W. S. Smith— I had omitted my usual morning walk.
27. IV:30. Walk to Capitol Square— Sun rose at 7:22

Mr Lowry the Secretary of the Senate, brought me six Resolutions of that body confirming nominations and advising and consenting to the Ratification of the three Indian Treaties sent to them— George Sullivan came to speak for Mr Richard Stockton, in behalf of Edward Thomson— A Son of Thomson is about to marry a daughter of Stockton, who is distressed with the apprehension of a criminal prosecution, and ignominious punishment as threatening to befall Thomson. Stockton, probably not yet aware of the extent of Thomson’s dishonesty thinks that he can still make the U.S. secure for the whole amount of his debt to them, and that by forbearance of a public prosecution he may be wrought upon to give that security— I advised Mr Sullivan to see and converse with Mr Rush upon the subject— Mr Garnett paid us a morning visit, but was unable to come up the Stairs—I went down to him. He had a fever last winter which confined him for almost the whole Session of Congress— His recovery was for many weeks considered desperate; and though convalescent ever since the Spring, he is yet unable to walk alone, and is now no more than an animated skeleton— Blunt came in, somewhat unexpectedly from New-York— I sent this day three Messages to the House of Representatives; in answer to Calls from them— One of them was a copy of the Message of Mr Jefferson to both Houses of Congress of 18 January 1803—and as that purported on the face of it to be secret and confidential, I sent it now in the same manner to the House; leaving it to them to determine whether it may be still expedient to keep it secret— The House removed the injunction of secrecy upon my Message, but not from that of Mr Jefferson— Mr Everett called this Evening, and told me, what occurred while they were sitting with closed doors. As a confidential message was announced some surprize was excited; and it was at first supposed that it related to the Panama Mission— After the Message of Mr Jefferson was read, the Virginians were alarmed with a fear of its being published; and Stevenson professed not to know for what purpose the call of it had been made— Trimble said, because it exhibited Mr Jefferson’s Views in regard to the civilization of the Indians Forsyth could not perceive that it was at all important whether it should be made public or not, but as it had been originally a secret Message, he thought it might as well be still considered as confidential; and moved it should be laid on the table, in which he was supported by Mr Webster, and as was accordingly done— Everett spoke of the fire in the Library of the Capitol; discovered by his wife, as they were returning from the party at Mr J. S. Johnstone’s—also of Hamilton’s proposed call of Papers relating to the Panama Mission
which Everett said was tartly expressed— I sent a Message to the Senate with the nominations for the Panama Mission, and the Correspondence, yesterday.
28. VI. Walk round the Tyber Square— 40 minutes.

Mr Coxe of Georgetown came with Joseph Morgan a Quaker and Judgment Debtor to the United States, against whom an Execution is about to issue to take his person— He presented a Memorial asking to be released from this judgment which he is unable to pay, and he brought a recommendation and certificate of character numerously attested, and warmly supported by Mr Coxe— I took the Memorial for reference to the District Attorney— General Van Rensselaer came to urge that Mr John Williams should be appointed Minister Plenipotentiary to the Federation of Central America, instead of Charge d’Affaires. Williams was a Senator from Tennessee, and two years since was superseded by the overpowering influence of General Jackson who was chosen in his place— He has ever since been kept under the harrow in the State, by the same power and was very solicitous to obtain this appointment of Chargé d’Affaires to Guatemala— But now that his is here and nominated to the Senate, some of his former associate partizans of Mr Crawford, have whispered to him that this Office of Charge d’Affaires is not of sufficient dignity for him, and that he is degrading himself by accepting it— General Van Rensselaer said he had agreed to mention this to me, and if the rank of the Mission could not be raised, to ask if I could not promise him something higher hereafter— I told the General that I should be happy to accommodate Mr Williams, and to gratify him— But the nomination was made— If I could even nominate again to the higher rank, Congress would probably not increase the appropriation, and I could make no promise for futurity, other than of goodwill and a friendly disposition— Messrs.Bartley and Wilson members of the House from Ohio came to speak in favour of the removal of a Land-Office to a place called Tiffin— Mr J. S. Ellery who came and was introduced by Mr Sullivan, said he should call again upon business of his own; an old claim upon the Chilian Government. Mr Rush was here twice—once upon the affairs of E. Thomson and the other time upon the case of C. J. Ingersoll— Upon a particular examination of the duties of the several Custom-house Officers by the Collection Law, I find reason to doubt the propriety of removing the Collector, at least for the present, and for believing that the chief responsibility for the losses by Thomson, ought properly to rest upon the Surveyor— Mr Rush was called out, by W. Findlay the Senator from Pennsylvania, who told him there would be great opposition made in the Senate to the renomination of C. J. Ingersoll as District Attorney for Pennsylvania—which is now before them—and Findlay proposed that the nomination should be withdrawn; and his brother Joseph Ingersoll nominated in his place— At the bottom of this opposition in the Senate is Mr Ingham of the House, who some time since sent me several papers proving a slight irregularity of practice by Ingersoll, in taking a fee
from the Assignees of a Bankrupt, for obtaining an accommodation of time, for the payment of a debt due by him to the United States— When Ingersoll was renominated in 1822. this same affair was investigated by a Committee of the Senate, and after understanding it thoroughly the Senate confirmed the nomination— It is now revived as a political intrigue with a view to displace Ingersoll. When Ingham sent me the papers I desired Mr Rush to inform him that the nomination of Mr Ingersoll had already been sent to the Senate, and that as that body had four years since confirmed the nomination of him with a full knowledge of this affair, I did not think it now a cause for withdrawing the nomination— Rush had given Ingersoll notice of the movements against him, and Ingersoll had sent him an explanation of the whole transaction, with documents which Mr Rush had left with me and which he now took to shew them to Findlay—with a hope of satisfying him that there is not sufficient ground for rejecting the nomination— Mr Clay gave an account of conversations with Baron Tuyll who has received instructions from his Government concerning our proposition that the Emperor Alexander should interpose to prevail on Spain to acknowledge the South American Republics, with a view to save to Spain the Islands of Cuba and Porto-Rico— Mr Clay has shewn to Baron Tuyll the notes he had written to the Ministers of Mexico and Columbia, to urge a suspension of any expedition against these Islands— Scott came to urge a speedy decision upon a claim of General Bissell to be ordered upon duty as if still of the army— He said a Senator had told him that the Senate would not suffer any other arrangement to be made— Genl. Macomb and Governor Cass of Michigan came for a morning visit. Mr Clark the Clerk of the House brought a Resolution from that body— Genl. Metcalfe and Mr Clarke, members of the House from Kentucky, called for a visit— J. Anderson and Burleigh, brought solicitations for a pardon to a man by the name of Amedey, convicted before the Circuit Court U.S. in Eastern Virginia, of having scuttled a ship to charge the Underwriters— He is supposed by the Petitioners to be under Sentence of death, and that nine of the Jury who found a verdict against him have recommended him to mercy. But I have no other knowledge of this. I had already received petitions numerously signed for his pardon, from Hingham where he has a wife and two children; and had directed a respite from Execution till further orders to be sent from the Department of State— My visitors kept me from breakfast till dinner time without intermission— In the Evening Mrs Adams had her second drawing-room which was much crowded— Mr Mills told me with a serious laugh that they had been trying me this day in the Senate, by a Resolution charging me with an assertion of usurped power— He said he would speak of it further to me hereafter— I said to Mr Lloyd also that I should be glad to converse with him concerning it— I sent this day to the Senate a Message with certain army nominations and
29. VI:30. Walk to Georgetown— Fog. Rain

The foul weather diminished the number of my visitors. Mr George Tucker called this morning with Mr Long and Mr Dunglason, two of the Professors at the newly established University near Mr Jefferson’s residence— Mr Tucker who had been a member of the two or three Congresses preceding the present, is now, the Professor of Moral Philosophy at the same University— The two others are Medical Professors and came from England. They speak of Mr Jefferson’s health as in a great measure restored— Mr Rush came with some further information and Letters concerning the disaster at the Custom House in Philadelphia, and concerning the objections in the Senate to the confirmation of the re-appointment of C. J. Ingersoll as District Attorney— It seems Ingersoll’s explanatory papers are so written that they cannot with propriety be communicated to Mr Findlay. Rush therefore concluded to send them back to Ingersoll so that he may expurgate them of their obnoxious matter so that they may be communicated here as mere explanations— Mr Powell, member of the house from Virginia and Mr Henry St. George Tucker called and paid a visit—as did Mr David Baker the clergyman, who introduced a Mr Patterson— I returned to Mr Baker his life of Whitfield, and Miller’s Letter against Unitarianism— He asked me what I thought of the last— I said they were well written, but to me, not convincing— There was a Mr Twitchel also who called— Mrs Adams was ill; confined almost the whole day to her bed— Mary and Selina Roberdeau dined with us.
Received a Resolution from the House—
30. VII. Stormy Night and Morning.— Attempted to walk and returned.

Mr Lowry brought me five Resolutions of the Senate— One, advising and consenting to the Ratification of the Treaty with the federation of Central America: the others confirming sundry nominations— Mr Rush was here, and read me Letters from the Collector at Philadelphia, Steele, and from the District Attorney Ingersoll upon the affair of Edward Thompson— There appears to be some variance between those Officers as to the mode of proceeding with him— Steele insists upon his being criminally prosecuted and confined in close prison— Ingersoll is for postponing severe measures and for a thorough-searching examination into his affairs upon his petition for a release from prison upon the executions of U.S. against him upon debt— I incline to this course myself— I am so little satisfied with the information which we have as yet obtained with regard to the facts, that I proposed to Mr Rush to despatch a trusty person to Philadelphia to examine minutely into the whole state of the Custom-house there and to take affidavits of all the Officers employed in that service, concerning the manner in which the office has been usually conducted, and particularly with regard to the facts connected with Thompson’s malpractices— Mr Rush agreed to this, and will apply to S. H. Smith, upon whom we fixed to be charged with this Commission.
Mr D. Brent brought from the Department of State a draft of a despatch to Mr Middleton at St. Petersburg, mentioning the applications we have made to the Governments of Colombia and Mexico, to prevail upon them to postpone any expedition that they may be projecting against the Islands of Cuba and Porto-Rico; to give time to the Emperor of Russia, to use in conjunction with his allies, his influence with Spain to induce her to save those Islands by recognizing the Independence of the new Governments on the American Continents— Mr Brent came also to ask the return of some papers to Mr Richard Bland Lee, which he had deposited here; and they were returned— They were recommendations of a person as a Justice of the Peace in this City— Mr Southard read me a Letter from Captain Morris at Paris, of 30. October— He was then on the point of proceeding upon his visit to the naval Military Establishments in the French Ports. I signed the Ratifications of three Indian Treaties— 1. With the Great and Little Osages. 2. With the Kansas. 3. With the Shawnese. Also Virginia Mily L-Warrants 2. We had company to dine— W. S. Archer— James and Mrs Barbour and their Son. T. W. Cobb, William Drayton— Benjamin and Mrs Estill, James and Mrs Findlay (of Ohio) Danl. G. Garnsey, Samuel Houston, Nehemiah R. and Mrs Knight, J. H. Marable. William Marks, Alfred H. Powell. John Rowan and his Son. Joshua Sands, James S. Stephenson (of Pennsylvania[)] George Tucker, Daniel and Mrs Webster, and John C. Wright— John Barney— Robert R. Rose and Henry Storrs did not come.
31. V:30. Walk to the Capitol Square.

Mr Goodsell came upon I know not what project— Mr Holmes to repeat the solicitations from Portland, for the pardon of Amedey. I told Mr Holmes what I had done; but that I believed no sentence of Death had passed upon the man— Mr George Peter is a member of the House of Representatives from Maryland; and Mr Dick whom he introduced to me is his nephew— Mills gave me a printed copy of the Resolution offered by Mr Branch to the Senate; declaring that the President of the United States has no right or power to appoint Ambassadors or Public Ministers, but with the advice and consent of the Senate; except in cases of vacancy which may happen during the recess of the Senate. It is preceded by a whereas the President of the United States did by his Message at the Commencement of the Senate, assert that Ministers would be commissioned to Panama, without submitting them to the Senate— And whereas though he did submit them to the Senate, he yet maintained the right of sending them without concurrence of the Senate— Therefore to guard against the precedent Resolved &c— I told Mills that the preamble or whereas upon which the Resolution was founded, was a statement incorrect in point of fact—charging me with having asserted that which I never did assert— I said I considered the Executive competent to institute a new Mission and appoint Ministers during the recess of the Senate, but that when the Senate were in Session they must be nominated. Mr Owen came to make some enquiry concerning a petition to Congress by a man name Robertson, who he said was one of his Constituents, and which the House of Representatives
by a Resolution two days since referred to the President of the United States— I said that besides the doubt whether the House alone could thus dispose of a petition addressed to the Congress, the reference itself to the President was a very unusual; I believed an unexampled thing— From respect to the House, I should preserve their Resolution of Reference with the documents, and endeavour to keep them choicely upon my files— Owen said he had thought it was not correct to make the reference to the President; and had told M’Lane so, the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, by whom the Resolution of reference was offered; but he said he was sure there was no intention of disrespect in the reference—of which I was well assured— I told Owen I would send him the petition and documents to do with them as he pleased. Mr. M’Kee, also of the House from Alabama called to visit me, and Mr Barbour the Secretary of War, brought me all the papers relating to the claim of General King to be restored to the appointment of Colonel of the second Regiment of Infantry now considered as vacant— Bissell’s claim is to be ordered upon duty, as having been constantly de jure in the Army— We had again company this day to dine— Mr and Mrs Frye, Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith— John Bishop of Charleston, and Mr Matthews the Rector of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick’s—and Captain T. Randall. Mr Blunt, G. Sullivan and Dr Huntt, were invited but could not come—Blunt is unwell. Miss Mease arrived here this Evening from Philadelphia.

Day and Year. The life that I lead is more regular than it has perhaps been at any other period of my life— It is established by custom that the President of the United States goes not abroad into any private companies, and to this usage I conform— I am therefore compelled to take my exercise, if at all in the morning before Breakfast— I rise usually between five and six; that is at this time of the year from an hour and a half to two hours before the Sun— I walk by the light of Moon or Stars, or none, about four miles, usually returning home in time to see the Sunrise from the Eastern chamber of the house— I then make my fire, and read three chapters of the Bible, with Scott’s and Hewlett’s Commentaries— Read papers till 9. Breakfast; and from ten, till five P.M. receive a succession of Visitors; sometimes without intermission—very seldom with an interval of half an hour— Never such as to enable me to undertake my business requiring attention— From five to half past six we dine; after which I pass about four hours in my chamber alone— Writing in this Diary, or reading papers upon some public business—excepting when occasionally interrupted by a visitor— Between eleven and twelve I retire to bed; to rise again symbols at 5 or 6 the next morning.

The year has been the most momentous of those that have passed over my head— Inasmuch as it has witnessed my elevation at the age of 58 to the Chief Magistracy of my Country— To the summit of laudable or at least blameless worldly ambition— Not however in a manner satisfactory to pride, or to just desire— Not by the unequivocal suffrages of a majority of the People— With perhaps two thirds of the whole people adverse to the actual result. Nearly one year of this service has already past, with little change of the public opinions or feelings— Without disaster to the Country; with an unusual degree of prosperity public and private symbols
